hard_constraints.translation: If the match ended 6–1, 6–2 for Dimitrov, then Dimitrov defeated Wawrinka.
hard_constraints.reasoning: In tennis reporting, the stated completed set scores (both sets) entail the match winner.

hard_constraints.translation: In this report, Dimitrov’s defeat of Wawrinka corresponds to the reported score 6–1, 6–2.
hard_constraints.evidence: “breeze through 6-1 , 6-2” describing Dimitrov’s win over Wawrinka.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Text ties the win claim to the explicit scoreline; to preserve the article’s intended reading, treat them as jointly fixed.

hard_constraints.translation: If Dimitrov defeated Wawrinka here, then he moved through to the quarter-finals (as a result).
hard_constraints.evidence: Win narrative + “Dimitrov moves through to the quarter-finals …”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Tournament advancement stated as consequence of the match outcome.

hard_constraints.translation: If Dimitrov is through to the quarter-finals, then he will meet Gael Monfils there.
hard_constraints.evidence: “… moves through to the quarter-finals where … will meet … Gael Monfils.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The ‘where’ clause attaches the opponent information to the quarter-final advancement.

hard_constraints.translation: Dimitrov’s ‘first Masters quarter-final of the season’ is the same quarter-final advancement described later.
hard_constraints.evidence: Opening: “to his first masters quarter-final of the season” + later: “moves through to the quarter-finals.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Both refer to the same event in the same match report; treating them as equivalent avoids duplicating two different quarter-finals.

hard_constraints.translation: Given Wawrinka was defending champion in Monte Carlo, losing 6–1 6–2 supports the characterization of a bizarre performance (as the article frames it).
hard_constraints.evidence: “Wawrinka is the defending champion in Monte Carlo …” + “A bizarre performance …” + lopsided scoreline.
hard_constraints.reasoning: This is a semantic coherence constraint reflecting the article’s internal framing: the ‘bizarre performance’ characterization is explained by context of defending champion + easy loss. (It enforces consistency of the report’s intent.)

hard_constraints.translation: Wawrinka’s four unforced errors in a row resulted in him surrendering his serve.
hard_constraints.evidence: “… made four unforced errors in a row to surrender his serve.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The infinitival ‘to’ marks the errors as leading to the serve loss; treated as entailing the outcome in the described episode.

hard_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka appeared out of sorts in the 6–1 6–2 defeat, then Dimitrov defeated Wawrinka.
hard_constraints.evidence: “… appeared out of sorts in the 6-1 6-2 defeat.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Calling it ‘the 6–1 6–2 defeat’ presupposes a loss by Wawrinka, i.e., a win by Dimitrov.

hard_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka only got on the board in the fifth game, that presupposes the match occurred and Wawrinka was being beaten (consistent with Dimitrov’s win).
hard_constraints.evidence: “failed to get on the board … until the fifth game” in the same match report describing Dimitrov’s easy win.
hard_constraints.reasoning: While not logically necessary in all worlds, within this single described match it semantically entails the match context and aligns with Dimitrov winning; we enforce it as a coherence constraint for this report.

hard_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka served to stay in the match at 5–2 down, that is consistent with and supports Dimitrov winning the match.
hard_constraints.evidence: “… served to stay in the match at 5-2 down …” followed by “Dimitrov was through …”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Being down 5–2 and needing to ‘stay in the match’ indicates Wawrinka was close to losing; combined with the narrative, it entails the match result as reported.

hard_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka made four tame unforced errors later (at 5–2 down), then Dimitrov was through to the last eight (quarter-finals).
hard_constraints.evidence: “Four tame unforced errors later and Dimitrov was through to the last eight.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Directly asserted causal/temporal link in the text.

hard_constraints.translation: If Dimitrov broke for a third time in the first set, then the first set ended 6–1 (as described).
hard_constraints.evidence: “broke for a third time and closed out the first set 6-1.”
hard_constraints.reasoning: The text narratively couples the third break with closing the set 6–1; treated as entailed within this report.

hard_constraints.translation: If the players shook hands at the end, then the match concluded with the reported outcome (Dimitrov defeating Wawrinka).
hard_constraints.evidence: Handshake caption immediately after the match description.
hard_constraints.reasoning: Handshake at the end presupposes match completion; within this article it is the same match whose outcome is Dimitrov’s win.

hard_constraints.translation: Magnus Norman was not in Monte Carlo this week.
hard_constraints.evidence: “Wawrinka 's coach Magnus Norman is not in Monte Carlo this week …”
hard_constraints.reasoning: Explicit negation stated as fact by the text.

soft_constraints.evidence: “He did not appear to be injured …”
soft_constraints.reasoning: The phrasing is appearance-based (epistemic/hedged); the text does not strictly assert absence of injury, only that it didn’t appear so.

soft_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka looked listless and disinterested, then he appeared out of sorts.
soft_constraints.evidence: Common-sense semantic relation; both descriptions are used together in the report.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Defeasible semantic inference: listless/disinterested demeanor typically implies being out of sorts, but not a strict logical necessity.

soft_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka’s performance was bizarre, then Wawrinka was disappointed at the end.
soft_constraints.reasoning: Likely correlation in context, but the text does not explicitly state disappointment is caused by the bizarre performance.

soft_constraints.translation: If Wawrinka had four winners and 41 unforced errors, then something was clearly wrong.
soft_constraints.evidence: “something was very clearly wrong; four winners and 41 unforced errors …”
soft_constraints.reasoning: The text argues this, but it’s an interpretive/diagnostic conclusion; treat as defeasible rather than strictly entailed by the stats alone.

soft_constraints.translation: If the crowd expected a thrilling encounter, then they would not be treated to an abject and mystifying performance.
soft_constraints.evidence: “would have expected a thrilling encounter … Instead, they were treated to an abject and mystifying performance …”
soft_constraints.reasoning: Expectation vs reality contrast suggests (but does not logically force) that the expectation was not met; defeasible because a thrilling match could still be described abjectly by a critic, though unlikely.
